action.action-desc: Mr. Manchin (for himself, Mrs. Boxer, and Mr. Rockefeller) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Environment and Public Works

form.official-title: To protect surface water from contamination by chemical storage facilities, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Chemical Safety and Drinking Water Protection Act of 2014.

section.header: Protection of surface water from contamination by chemical storage facilities

subsection.text: The Safe Drinking Water Act (42 U.S.C. 300f et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

part.header: Protection of surface water from contamination by chemical storage facilities

subparagraph.text: The term covered chemical storage facility means a facility at which a chemical is stored and the Administrator or State, as applicable, determines that a release of the chemical from the facility poses a risk of harm to a public water system.

The term covered chemical storage facility does not include a facility that is subject to a procedure, method, or other requirement for equipment to address hazardous substances pursuant to section 311(j)(1)(C) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1321(j)(1)(C)).

In determining risk of harm posed by a chemical storage facility under subparagraph (A), the Administrator or State, as applicable, may consider the requirements of applicable Federal or State laws (including regulations).

paragraph.text: The term State program means a chemical storage facility source water protection program established under section 1472.

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this part, the Administrator or each State exercising primary enforcement responsibility for public water systems, as applicable, shall carry out, directly or through delegation, a chemical storage facility source water protection program to provide for the protection of public water systems from a release of a chemical from a covered chemical storage facility.

paragraph.text: A State program under subsection (a) shall provide for oversight and inspection of each covered chemical storage facility in accordance with the requirements described in paragraph (2) to prevent the release of chemicals into the water supply in watersheds with public water systems that rely on surface water, including a covered chemical storage facility located in a source water area identified under section 1453.
At a minimum, a State program shall include—

subparagraph.text: requirements for covered chemical storage facilities, including—

clause.text: acceptable standards of good design, construction, or maintenance;
an emergency response and communication plan;
an employee training and safety plan;
an inspection of the integrity of each covered chemical storage facility;
notice to the Administrator, the appropriate State agency, and applicable public water systems of—

subclause.text: the potential toxicity of the stored chemicals to humans and the environment; and
safeguards or other precautions that can be taken to detect, mitigate, or otherwise limit the adverse effects of a release of the stored chemicals; and

clause.text: financial responsibility requirements, including proof of insurance, bond, or other similar instrument;

subparagraph.text: inspections of covered chemical storage facilities, which shall occur—

clause.text: for a covered chemical storage facility identified in a source water assessment area under section 1453, not less frequently than once every 3 years; and
for any other covered chemical storage facility, not less frequently than once every 5 years; and

subparagraph.text: a comprehensive inventory of the covered chemical storage facilities in each State.

subsection.text: For purposes of primary enforcement responsibility, a State program and any requirements under this part shall be—

paragraph.text: considered to be a part of the national primary drinking water regulations established under section 1412; and
implemented and enforced in accordance with the procedures under sections 1413 and 1414 and part E.

subsection.text: A State program shall be carried out—

paragraph.text: if the State exercises primary enforcement responsibility for public water systems in that State under this Act, by the State; and
if the State does not exercise primary enforcement responsibility for public water systems in that State under this Act, by the Administrator.

subsection.text: The Administrator may issue guidance or provide other technical assistance to State programs in carrying out activities under this part.

section.text: The Administrator under section 1472(d)(2) or the State under section 1472(d)(1), as applicable, may issue an order to the owner or operator of a covered chemical storage facility to carry out this part.

If costs have been incurred by the Administrator or the State, as applicable, for undertaking a response action under this part relating to the release of a chemical, the owner or operator of the covered chemical storage facility shall be liable to the Administrator or the State for those costs.

section.header: Transfer of covered chemical storage facilities
section.text: Notwithstanding the inspection schedule under section 1472(b)(2)(B), no person shall transfer a covered chemical storage facility unless—

paragraph.text: prior to the closing or completion of the transfer, the transferor submits to the transferee the results of a pretransfer inspection of the integrity of the covered chemical storage facility, which shall be conducted pursuant to any requirements set by the Administrator under section 1472(d)(2) or the State under section 1472(d)(1), as applicable; and

the transferor or the transferee agrees to take appropriate measures to address the results of the pretransfer inspection prior to the date that is 30 days after the date on which the covered chemical storage facility closes or is transferred.

subsection.text: The Administrator or State, as applicable, shall provide public water systems with information relating to—

paragraph.text: emergency response plans for covered chemical storage facilities located within the same watershed as the public water system; and
an inventory of each chemical held at the covered chemical storage facilities described in paragraph (1).

subsection.text: A copy of each emergency response plan submitted under section 1472(b)(2)(A) shall be provided to—

paragraph.text: the Administrator (if the State exercises primary responsibility for public water systems in that State); and
the Secretary of Homeland Security.

The Administrator or a State, as applicable, may keep confidential information the Administrator or the State determines to be sensitive and present a security risk to a covered chemical storage facility.
Paragraph (1) shall not—

subparagraph.text: apply to public health information; or
prevent the sharing of information with the Administrator, the Secretary of Homeland Security, a public water system, or a public agency involved in emergency response.

subsection.text: Section 1431 of the Safe Drinking Water Act (42 U.S.C. 300i) is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating subsection (b) as subsection (c); and
by inserting after subsection (a) the following:
In any case in which the Administrator is authorized to act under subsection (a), the owner or operator of a public water system may—

subparagraph.text: commence a civil action for appropriate equitable relief, including a restraining order or permanent or temporary injunction, to address any activity or facility that may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to the health of persons who are supplied by that public water system; or
petition the Administrator to issue an order or commence a civil action under subsection (a).

Subject to subparagraph (B), not later than 30 days after the date on which the Administrator receives a petition under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall respond to the petition and initiate such action as the Administrator determines to be appropriate.

If the owner or operator of a public water system submits the petition under paragraph (1) in response to an emergency, the Administrator shall respond not later than 72 hours after receipt of the petition.

subsection.text: Section 1414 of the Safe Drinking Water Act (42 U.S.C. 300g–3) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsections (a), (b), (e), (f), and (g)—

subparagraph.text: by inserting after public water system each place it appears or a covered chemical storage facility; and
by inserting after public water systems each place it appears or a covered chemical storage facility; and

paragraph.text: in subsection (i)—

subparagraph.text: by redesignating paragraphs (1) through (3) as subparagraphs (A) through (C), respectively, and indenting appropriately;
by striking the heading designation and all that follows through means— and inserting the following:

paragraph.text: The term applicable requirement means—

clause.text: by inserting a comma after 1417; and
by striking or 1445 and inserting 1445, or part G; and

subparagraph.text: by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The term covered chemical storage facility has the meaning given the term in section 1471.
